subject: Re: [junit] Re: Theories::computeTestMethods correct collection usage?
msgSnippet: done...2196462 ;) ... -- Raphael Parree CTO SOA Evangelist Trivera Technologies Global J2EE Education, Mentoring, Courseware & Consulting Services phone:+31
messageBody:
done...2196462 ;)


On Fri, Oct 24, 2008 at 7:05 PM, Raphael Parree <rparree@...> wrote:

> David,
>
>
> The following code:
>
> @RunWith(Theories.class)
> public class FooTest {
> public static int VALUE=1;
> @Test
> public void bar(int i) {
> System.out.println("bar:" +i);
>
> }
> }
>
> Produces the result: bar:1
>
> Which i believe is the result of the code i was referring to...
>
> Raphael
>
>
>
>
>
> On Fri, Oct 24, 2008 at 7:09 PM, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
>> I'm pretty sure it won't run a parameterized method as a Theory
>> without @Theory, but I'm willing to be proven wrong.
>>
>> David Saff
>>
>>
>> On Fri, Oct 24, 2008 at 3:19 AM, Raphael Parree <rparree@...<rparree%40gmail.com>>
>> wrote:
>> > Hi,
>> >
>> > However .. (i know i am just talking to myself here)
>> >
>> > This means that the @Theory annotation is optional and you can also just
>> use
>> > a @Test (the Theories also adds the regular test methods) If you only
>> use
>> > @Test and no @Theory, then the removeAll removes none, and the addAll
>> adds
>> > none. leaving you with all the Test methods which means the @Theory
>> > annotation is not significant, but only the runner is.
>> >
>> > Is this the expected behaviour ?
>> >
>> > Raphael
>> >
>> > On Wed, Oct 22, 2008 at 6:42 PM, Raphael Parree <rparree@...<rparree%40gmail.com>>
>> wrote:
>> >
>> >> Hi,
>> >>
>> >> Sorry i guess this code is making sure that if a method is annotaed
>> with
>> >> both annotations it will not be executed double. It is kind of
>> mimicking a
>> >> set that way.
>> >>
>> >> Raphael
>> >>
>> >>
>> >> On Wed, Oct 22, 2008 at 4:01 PM, Raphael Parree <rparree@...<rparree%40gmail.com>>
>> wrote:
>> >>
>> >>> Hi,
>> >>>
>> >>> Am i missing something in the code below
>> >>> (org.junit.experimental.theories.Theories)
>> >>>
>> >>> @Override
>> >>> protected List<FrameworkMethod> computeTestMethods() {
>> >>> List<FrameworkMethod> testMethods= super.computeTestMethods();
>> >>> List<FrameworkMethod> theoryMethods=
>> >>> getTestClass().getAnnotatedMethods(Theory.class);
>> >>> testMethods.removeAll(theoryMethods);
>> >>> testMethods.addAll(theoryMethods);
>> >>> return testMethods;
>> >>> }
>> >>>
>> >>> I am referring to these lines:
>> >>>
>> >>> testMethods.removeAll(theoryMethods);
>> >>> testMethods.addAll(theoryMethods);
>> >>>
>> >>> Isn't the second line just undoing the one before it?
>> >>>
>> >>> Raphael
>> >>>
>> >>>
>> >>
>> >>
